title_review: Neat little suburban eatery, but stuck in a bit of a time warp.
review_preview: We were looking for an "event" night meal out in Madrid, having tossed about a few ideas in the city we instead decided, on the strength of the TripAdvisor reviews, to head out to La Tena restaurant, about 45 minutes by metro and a 10...
review_full: We were looking for an "event" night meal out in Madrid, having tossed about a few ideas in the city we instead decided, on the strength of the TripAdvisor reviews, to head out to La Tena restaurant, about 45 minutes by metro and a 10 minute walk from Sol. It's clearly on the radar for foreign tourists, while we were there the restaurant had just 3 tables booked, Americans, a Japanese couple, and us ( Australian), there were no local Spanish diners to be seen. Why that would be the case we don't know, but we are always suspicious of places where the locals don't eat. However, it was a pretty good experience despite that, nothing great to be fair, but still nothing to complain about. Our waiter helped us out by suggesting, through sign language, that we wouldn't need to order two entrÃ©e meals as well as a main each as the entree's are large, that was helpful and appreciated. The menu was, for us, slightly confusing, we normally would order an entrÃ©e and a main each with perhaps a side salad depending on the restaurant, La Tena has a menu, like many Spanish places, where if you order a salad, it's actually a full sized main course meal, thus we ordered just an entrÃ©e and a main each, leaving out the salad, in hindsight we should have gone with a salad, the mains were a good size but with no fresh light salad to compliment it we thought it lacked a little. That was our fault though and if a return visit was on the cards we would go with shared entrÃ©e, shared salad and main each. The wine list is quite small, made smaller by the many wines crossed out as unavailable, also we would have normally had a glass of white with entrÃ©e followed by a shared bottle of red, there did not seem to be any wines by the glass so we stuck with a bottle of very nice Spanish Sauvignon Blanc, but for me, my main needed a red wine and with no options by the glass we skipped the red. Our mains of confit duck and a turbot dish with a citrus foam (foam! didn't we leave foams behind 10 years ago) were both ok, but nothing special to be fair. The dessert was actually not very good at all, a deconstructed (didn't we leave that idea behind as well) cheesecake served in one of those jam jars that I know we did leave behind some years ago. Another thing that struck us was the restaurant was pretty much empty, ok, it was only 10pm when we were eating and perhaps the locals were still on their way, but they had the three full tables all jammed together in one corner which was somewhat claustrophobic and in a quiet environment when you can hear every little eve-dropping conversation we would have liked to be a bit more spread out. Add in the hour or so each way travel and we think we would have been better off staying in town and hunting down a contemporary restaurant there.

title_review: Well worth a small detour from the centre...
review_preview: This excellent Basque restaurant run by two brothers (in the footsteps of their parents) is a 6 minute walk from Las Ventas Metro on the east side of the city.We were invited by Basque friend who has been a faithful client over the years....
review_full: This excellent Basque restaurant run by two brothers (in the footsteps of their parents) is a 6 minute walk from Las Ventas Metro on the east side of the city. We were invited by Basque friend who has been a faithful client over the years. The food was superb. We shared three starters between three: fresh anchovies roasted in the oven with garlic; a delicious creamy 'revuelto de pisto' (eggs scrambled into ratatouille) and clams in a very tasty sauce. My main course was a house speciality: lightly fried hake in batter on a blank ink squid sauce. And for dessert 'leche frita' (literally fried milk). A real gastronomic experience at sensible prices.

title_review: Classic Basque Cuisine -- nothing too Fancy (or original)
review_preview: This is a restaurant that has been around for 40 years and has found a successful formula that enables it to open only Monday through Friday.  The food is standard Basque fare, but of a high quality in both ingredients and preparation.  You really can't...
review_full: This is a restaurant that has been around for 40 years and has found a successful formula that enables it to open only Monday through Friday. The food is standard Basque fare, but of a high quality in both ingredients and preparation. You really can't go wrong here, and the menu has a helpful key that lets you know just what each dish contains (with the odd exception of meat -- they need to add a symbol for meat, which as is always the case in Spain, appears in many dishes not listed under the meat category on the menu). Portions are a little on the small size, so I wouldn't come here if you're ravenous. Very good and moderately priced wine list. Service is exceptionally efficient and friendly.

review_preview: My wife and I went to this year's NYE dinner. We weren't aware it was a fixed menu when we reserved a spot, but Maria (the owner) sent us an email a couple weeks out. We happily agreed to keep the reservation as the menu...
review_full: My wife and I went to this year's NYE dinner. We weren't aware it was a fixed menu when we reserved a spot, but Maria (the owner) sent us an email a couple weeks out. We happily agreed to keep the reservation as the menu looked awesome and the cost was much better than most we saw in Madrid for NYE. We didn't realize the meal started at 8:30pm, but thankfully Maria sent a reminder email earlier in the day. While the food was very good, what really stood out was the attitude of the staff and pace of the evening. It was almost as if the staff had invited us all to their NYE celebration. They were super attentive, happy and celebratory throughout the night and joined us in ringing in the new year with cava and grapes at midnight. The meal was also perfectly paced so that none of the night felt rushed. Overall, the staff created a very relaxing but celebratory environment - exactly what we wanted that evening.

Panocota topped off our best dinner in Madrid. Service was excellent. At less than $20, including a bottle of wine this place is a treasure.

review_full: This is an incredibly popular spot in Sol, Madrid. We tried to do a drop in dinner at around 8pm and were greeted by a Alejandra, the hostess, who let us know there were no seatings available before 11 pm. Unfortunately we had a very early start to begin our trek back home to Canada so we knew we'd have to miss this fantastic tapas bar which had come highly recommend...when we let Alejandra know, she kindly let us know we may be able to get a quick meal in if we were able to do so in 45 minutes before a large reservation arrived... We jumped at the opportunity and were not disappointed at all! Alejandra made sure we had very fast and friendly service, and the tapas and sangria we enjoyed were delicious! We're so grateful Alejandra was able to accommodate us on such short notice because we wouldn't have had this experience on our last night in Spain if she hadn't taken the time to be creative with seating options. We will definitely come again for a pre-planned longer meal and we highly recommend it if you get the chance - delicious food and excellent service... definitely a good idea to book in advance if you're able to!

title_review: maybe my new favorite place in Madrid
review_preview: Just back from my first visit, lunch, at Amicis, after reading the TA reviews and noticing the approving pattern, which I will now add to.  Nestled back behind the delirious San Miguel Market, Amicis is a Centro staple now under new ownership/management, and the effort...
review_full: Just back from my first visit, lunch, at Amicis, after reading the TA reviews and noticing the approving pattern, which I will now add to. Nestled back behind the delirious San Miguel Market, Amicis is a Centro staple now under new ownership/management, and the effort really shows. The cocktails are imaginative, the wine list is great, the menu is authentic and diverse but tourist friendly, the sound track is great, the space(s) are all comfortable whether in or out or up or down, and the staff are all attentive and attractive and multi-lingual and really dedicated to your having a good experience and a great time. I had my lunch at the bar after I noticed that, ever so often when he thought no one was looking, bartender Mano would burst into dance, which I thought was just too charming to leave for a table and miss. This is a good place, and I will certainly go back for more.

review_preview: Booked the restaurant during the day after reading reviews on Google and Trip Advisor for 830pm. The restaurant was already busy so very glad we booked. We had tapas ( patatas bravas, honey fried aubergine, potatoe croquettes) followed by the surf and turf paella and...
review_full: Booked the restaurant during the day after reading reviews on Google and Trip Advisor for 830pm. The restaurant was already busy so very glad we booked. We had tapas ( patatas bravas, honey fried aubergine, potatoe croquettes) followed by the surf and turf paella and bottle of Ribuero Del Duero Temporanillo. The wine was only â‚¬12 and had a great flavour. The food was very delicious and probably the best bravas I've had even in Seville or Barcelona. The paella was amazing with king prawns, mussels, chicken and octopus. The atmosphere in the restaurant is just the best and we were served by Monty from Egypt. He was very friendly and had a lovely way with all customers going the extra mile to talk to customers and make them feel welcome. Would go back tomorrow but sadly have returned home. Go you will not be disappointed but worth booking especially after seeing the queues waiting to go in when we left.

title_review: Very professional staff who serve excellent food in a wonderful location
review_preview: Madrid has many restaurants in which you can sit in the glorious sun and enjoy reasonably good food and so-so service and you will leave feeling you have had a wonderful experience. If you want to have really great food, sun and superb service, go...
review_full: Madrid has many restaurants in which you can sit in the glorious sun and enjoy reasonably good food and so-so service and you will leave feeling you have had a wonderful experience. If you want to have really great food, sun and superb service, go to Amicis. They have fantastic food (the salads are amazing) and top quality service from a team run by Fabio and Maria. The staff are clearly well trained (our waiter, Manuel from Venezuela) was exceptional and Fabio and Maria did what really good restaurateurs do i.e. monitor all the tables and make sure the guests are happy. If you come to Madrid for a holiday or live here, Amicis should be at the top of your list for places to eat. A fantastic 5 star experience.

review_preview: Visited with friends and family for a spot of lunch. The owners work in the restaurant, Fabio is front of house, Maria the business lady - perfect combo. The position is great, children can play in the square to the front- shade or sun and...
review_full: Visited with friends and family for a spot of lunch. The owners work in the restaurant, Fabio is front of house, Maria the business lady - perfect combo. The position is great, children can play in the square to the front- shade or sun and very safe. We relaxed at our outside table with ours in full view.  Service was totally on point, English and Spanish, and our waiter Miguel also very helpful and friendly. Timely service too. Attentive but not overly so, nothing too much trouble.  Both service and food is important to us and the menu did not disappoint. Think fresh, healthy but indulgent. We enjoyed salads; crispy kale with couscous and apricot. House salad was chicken and avocado lightly dressed with crisp leaves.  Our 6 year old was treated as a princess, with cracked eggs and ham and gorgeous chocolate ice cream to follow. The wine list is more than adequate for those who appreciate a good bottle.  Most importantly though we were made to feel exceptionally welcome and we could have stayed there all afternoon save for a sightseeing date with the Spanish Palace! One to definitely put on your list - and youâ€™ll go back again Iâ€™d bet!

Flowers, Paintings, lamps, Flamingo party room! Just wow! We ordered: *2 Cocktails presented in such amazing art.  First cocktail: Served in a hatched layed in feathers It tasted amazing. And the flavor was a surprise! Second cocktail: Served in a Science glass and when opened smoke came out! So awesome! Another surprise :) *Beef platter: WOW best meat ever! *Tortilla: Obvi best tortilla in town, without a doubt! *Crocettes with ham inside (to drool over) *Mushroom soup- awesome topped with the Beef platter!  *Mozzerella- O M G to diiiiie for, food orgasm !!! They also own another Restaurant (see Picture) We did not have a chance to go there but recommend with 10% off.  All in all it was an amazing experience!  Unfortunatly the food and drinks were SO good i forgot to make pics haha They were gone in no time!  Cheers to Ale Ale Jandro and Monty and the whole team of Rosi La Loca â¤ï¸â¤ï¸â¤ï¸ Until next time! Stay how you are and never change you guys are seriously amazing!  Askar and Cassie With love from Toledo
